bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, December 14, 1938

div1.p: Hench informs Moran that he is resolved to write an accurate history of the yellow fever experiments. He discusses the relative reliability of Moran's and Kissinger's recollections.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, December 14, 1938
div1.opener:
Yellow Fever
December 14, 1938
Mr. John J. Moran
c/o Cia. Sunoco de Cuba, S. A.
Avenida Menocal Nos. 455-57
Habana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
I frankly admit that I was quite relieved to receive your recent letter, as I was
afraid that perhaps you had taken a little offense at my frank remarks. I do appreciate
your comments very much indeed, and I am delighted to have the honor of having received
your autographed photographs.

My little, modest idea of writing a short account of the story of yourself and
Kissinger for staff meeting here has become considerably complicated. I little dreamed
that there were so many conflicting features about the yellow fever researches. I
can well see how anxious you are to have some of these conflicts straightened out for
the sake of future medical historians. I am flattered by your suggestion that I should
make a much more comprehensive study, not just one of the parts played by yourself
and Kissinger, and your suggestion that I become deeply involved in trying to rewrite
in a more accurate fashion a history of the yellow fever researches is flattering and
at the same time very intriguing. I am a very busy physician (at least I like to think
I am) doing clinical work and medical research here of an amount that keeps me hustling.
Nevertheless, I have always been extremely interested in medical history, and the idea
of devoting part of my time over the next several months or years toward the yellow
fever story is not at all distasteful. I believe I told you that when I was in England
this Spring, haunting some old medical bookstores, I ran across several interesting
old books on yellow fever, before the time of Reed, and one written just a few years
after the work in Cuba. I bought these with glee and they will be helpful in my
background notes. I sincerely hope I will be able to continue to have your most
appreciated cooperation in this matter.

I wish to reiterate my complete sympathy with both you and Kissinger, and my
understanding of reasons which might make your stories disagree in detail but not in
principle. Having spent several hours on at least two occasions with Mr. Kissinger,
it is not difficult to realize that from the standpoint of memory, the word of one who
has had considerably more education than Mr. Kissinger was able to have, carries much
weight. For the next two weeks I will be able to do nothing on the problem, and this
is one of those things that will have to occupy my spare hours from time to time, very
intermittently. Rest assured that I am keeping at it, and nothing will happen in any
way, shape or form until you have had the chance to see it and criticize it in extense.
This is not my story. It is the story of those who did the work, and I am merely the
medium for the story.

Again I regret that I did not know of your living in Havana two years ago when
I was there. I hope to go to California for my vacation this Spring, but next Winter
Mr. John J. Moran
- 2 -
December 14, 1938
expect to go to Florida. If we are both in the land of the living I sincerely
hope to run over to visit you in Havana at that time--in other words, fourteen
months from now.
With the best of Christmas wishes, I remain,
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
